thread.title: 'Seriousness of purpose' in PM's innovation roundtable
thread.title_full: 'Seriousness of purpose' in PM's innovation roundtable | afr.com

author: Ben Potter
title: 'Seriousness of purpose' in PM's innovation roundtable
text:
Malcolm Turnbull has compiled a list of innovators he can talk about later this year. Andrew Meares by Ben Potter Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull assembled a who's who of start-ups, technology companies, university and public agency researchers for his innovation roundtable on Friday to gather ideas for an innovation statement later this year.
Freelancer.com founder Matt Barrie; Seek.com founders Paul and Andrew Bassatt; CHAMP private Equity founder and co-chairman Bill Ferris; Google Australia boss Maile Carnegie; Telstra chief operating officer Kate McKenzie; and Reinventure Group co-founder Danny Gilligan; led the business contingent at the roundtable.
But what encouraged Roy Green, dean of management at Sydney's University of Technology, was that the Prime Minister was joined at the meeting at Western Sydney University in Penrith by all the ministers whose portfolios bear on innovation.
They included Industry, Science and Innovation Minister Christopher Pyne and his departmental secretary, assistant innovation minister Wyatt Roy; Special Minister advising the Prime Minister, Arthur Sinodinos, and the deputy secretary of the department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and assistant science minister, Karen Andrews.
"For me that symbolised the seriousness of purpose of our new Prime Minister in venturing into this space and making it a key element of his government's program," said Professor Green.
"This will be a differentiator for him not just for symbolic reasons but because we have reached a point in our economic history where measures in this space are more urgent and essential than ever."
Range of issues They discussed a wide range of issues involved in boosting Australia's poor record on innovation and commercialisation of the impressive output of publicly funded research, which costs $9.7 billion and rates in the global top eight but ranks much lower when it comes to turning ideas into businesses.
 These included tax and other incentives offered by countries such as Singapore, Israel and Britain to attract and retain entrepreneurs and creators of intellectual property, and to encourage them to turn their ideas into businesses, and attract investment.
Fiona Scott, federal member for Lindsay, which includes Penrith, said: "Today's meeting is the first step in breaking through the innovation glass ceiling in Australia."
Professor Green said there were "no particular action points but it's all being taken away for the purpose of the Prime Minister developing his government's innovation statement."
CSIRO chief executive Larry Marshall; Western Sydney University vice-chancellor and Universities Australia chairman Barry Glover; and Doron Ben Meir, head of Research, Innovation and Commercialisation at Melbourne University; filled out the university and research contingent.
